posts.text:
Agentic frameworks didnâ€™t evolve into a necessity, they exploded into one. 

Today, they are becoming as foundational to AI development as Kubernetes is to cloud computing.

Back in 2014, when Kubernetes launched, cloud computing was chaos.

Companies were deploying containerized apps across multiple environments, each with different APIs, configs, and deployment models. Managing them manually was practically impossible.

Then Kubernetes came along, as a single orchestrator to abstract away the pain and completely reshape the cloud ecosystem.

Fast forward to today: weâ€™re at the same inflection point with LLMs.

Agentic frameworks promise to do for AI what Kubernetes did for cloud:

â€¢ Orchestrate reasoning
â€¢ Manage tool usage
â€¢ Handle human feedback loops
â€¢ Schedule tasks
â€¢ Bridge the gap from chat to action

As Kubernetes does, they orchestrate complex systems by managing tasks, resources, and feedback loops at scale.

On top of that, agentic frameworks also also make debugging, evaluating, and benchmarking AI-driven apps far easier.

The ecosystem is exploding: LangChain, OpenAIâ€™s Agents SDK, Google ADK, NVIDIAâ€™s NeMo, Hugging Face smolagents, deepset's Haystackâ€¦ you name it.

But I still hear some developers asking the same couple of questions:

Why do we even need them?
Isnâ€™t it all just about calling model APIs?

My answer:

Not anymore. Calling GPT-5 or Claude directly is like deploying containers manually on bare-metal servers. Sure, it works, until a vendor introduces a breaking API change. As AI agents grow more complex, we need orchestration: coordinating tools, chaining tasks, injecting guardrails, and managing context across systems.

So the most popular frameworks are not just connecting APIs, they are defining the standards of how LLM-powered systems reason, act, and scale.

Tech battles are heating up at every corner of the AI field ğŸ¿

Which framework do you think will end up dominating the market?

posts.text:
My dad was a civil engineer who particularly liked bridges. He told me stories of how tiny, unexpected phenomena could bring down massive projects, like the London Millennium Bridge in 2000, shaken by a new vibration effect later called â€œsynchronous lateral excitation.â€

I believe weâ€™re at a similar turning point in software engineering.

LLMs are forcing us into the world of non-determinism and uncertainty that other engineering fields have faced for millennia.

I remember when non-determinism hit my "product software" for the first time:

Early in my career, I built a feature and every test case passed perfectly on my computer. But in the clientâ€™s PC the app triggered a weird error half the time for no apparent reason. I assumed Iâ€™d made a mistake. But no, it was the noise of reality injecting variability I hadnâ€™t accounted for. Back then, those situations were rare, and I was both confused and frustrated.

I expected my code to behave deterministically, all the time! (yeah, I didnâ€™t have much experience 20 years ago).

Now, with LLMs, unpredictability is the assumption rather than the exception.

And as engineers, we shouldnâ€™t be surprised, because most other engineering disciplines already take variability very seriously:

âœ“ Process engineers design systems knowing humans make mistakes.
âœ“ Structural engineers account for forces they canâ€™t measure or fully predict.
âœ“ Biomedical engineers design devices knowing theyâ€™ll behave differently in every patient.

Software engineering, though, has always been perceived as different.

Our machines were deterministic: the same input produced the same output, almost always.

LLMs just broke that fantasy. Two identical prompts can yield completely different answers.

Determinism is gone, and with it, the old certainty of how software â€œshouldâ€ behave.

The shift isnâ€™t optional. 

If we want to thrive in the age of AI, we must learn to engineer for unpredictability, by default.

Like with bridges, our software now has to sway with the wind, or risk collapsing under forces we didnâ€™t plan for at first.

Good friends have asked me how I manage to type so fast without even looking at the keyboard.

The secret is touch typing.

Itâ€™s a skill I learned more than 20 years ago (ouch, I just felt old after writing this line).

Back then, I used a small Windows XP app that taught me the basics. Today, you can find a modern version called TIPP10.

After just a couple of days of practice, I was already typing without glancing.

The trick to mastering this is to follow the Ten-Finger System.

Hereâ€™s the basic idea:

â‘  Place your left-hand fingers on A, S, D, F and your right-hand fingers on J, K, L. Thumbs rest on the space-bar.

â‘¡ Each finger is responsible for specific keys (see the attached figure below for a precise finger-to-key mapping).

â‘¢ Always return to the home row after pressing any key.

â‘£ Focus on the text, not the keyboard. This helps you spot typos immediately.

â‘¤ Accuracy comes first. Speed naturally improves with practice.

This system saves time because you donâ€™t have to constantly shift from the screen to the keyboard and back again (added bonus: you can see mistakes as they happen on the screen).

For me, the time invested was really worth it, considering that Iâ€™ve benefited from it all my life.

Butâ€¦ does typing faster make any difference?

Honestly, not always. As a software developer, I spend more time reading code and THINKING than actually typing. But when you do need to write quickly, itâ€™s incredibly handy, e.g. when I'm chatting, emailing, or writing a random LinkedIn post about touch typing ğŸ˜

If you want to try it out for free, hereâ€™s a link to TIPP10: https://www.tipp10.com

P.S. Having a good keyboard also contributes to type faster, and Iâ€™m a huge mechanical keyboard nerd. Iâ€™ve built my own keyboards piece by piece, customized keycaps, hand-lubed switches, etc. Butâ€¦ thatâ€™s content for another post.

In a world where AI can answer, summarize, explain, and predict, I think the game isnâ€™t about acquiring knowledge. Itâ€™s knowing what to ask and how to execute on top of it.

The current situation is nothing new. Letâ€™s look a bit into history.

In 1440, Johannes Gutenberg introduced the printing press.

Suddenly, Europe experienced an explosion of information. For the first time in history, books werenâ€™t scarce artifacts chained to monastery walls. Books became cheap, abundant, and widely accessible.

Within a few decades, anyone who could read had access to the same texts: Aristotle, Euclid, the Bible, and scientific treatises. Knowledge stopped being a privilege of the elite.

Howeverâ€¦

Most people didnâ€™t become groundbreaking thinkers overnight just because they had access to more information. They were flooded with answers but lacked the skills to think out of the box and ask the right questions.

Meanwhile, a few guys like Copernicus, Galileo, and Kepler made groundbreaking achievements.

Why?

Because they challenged assumptions:

ğŸ”¹ What if the Earth isnâ€™t the center of the universe?
ğŸ”¹ What if gravity explains planetary motion?

These werenâ€™t answers to those hidden in books. They were original questions no one else dared to ask. There was no existing knowledge about it.

Fast forward to today: AI is our modern printing press. We all have access to the same â€œanswering machine.â€ And the real differentiator isnâ€™t knowing more, itâ€™s knowing what to ask, how to squeeze LLMs, and how to extrapolate from the answers it gives to us.

Indeed, I believe that the art of questioning is becoming more and more relevant with AI:

âœ“ Great questions unlock better AI responses.
âœ“ They spark deeper (more human-like) conversations.
âœ“ They lead to better decisions, faster.

What if LinkedIn loses every single post youâ€™ve ever written? Years of ideas. Gone. Iâ€™ve realized that we donâ€™t actually own what we publish here! So, I built a solution.

Having a hard time figuring out whatâ€™s going on in a bunch of Python error logs? Feeling lost in the traceback?

Spending a lot of time staring at console logs looking for runtime edge cases is a common thing. No dev can escape from it, especially now that understanding AI outputs is so critical.

And youâ€™re right, the Python compiler still has a lot of room for improvement when it comes to developer experience.

The underlying reason is that the Python compiler intentionally defers many checks to runtime. The upside is speed of iteration, the downside is that you discover certain mistakes only when the buggy instruction is executed.

Itâ€™s just an issue in Python that we all have to deal with.

Is there a solution?

Not really, but you can use libraries that enhance the debugging experience.

In particular, Iâ€™ve been using a Python library called â€œrichâ€ lately for this purpose.

Rich adds custom colors, formatting, and metadata to the logs, making issue tracking an entirely different experience for developers.

Want an enhanced traceback?

Just import `install` from `rich.traceback` and run `install()` in the beginning of your script (see example below ğŸ‘‡). 

It makes errors clearer in the console by pretty-printing and pointing directly to the line that triggered the error.

Rich also offers a nice way to display the value of local variables in functions, very useful for debugging!

Try it out, youâ€™ll seeâ€¦ going back to raw logs will feel like a â€œno way, dude.â€

posts.text:
Iâ€™d argue that as the value of gathering existing knowledge goes down, the value of creating new knowledge should go up.

We've all seen how AI has drastically changed the value of knowledge in the last few years.

I remember, when I was 10, I had only a few old books at home (the new ones either werenâ€™t available or they were too expensive). If I wanted to read good stuff, I had to walk to the local library and sit down there to read.

When I was 20, I remember that university professors were respected for the sheer amount of knowledge they had accumulated over a lifetime. We valued them because their skills and expertise were scarce.

Now, in my 30s, knowledge is everywhere. Itâ€™s cheaper than ever and moves at lightspeed. A curious 10-year-old today can access cutting-edge tools and learn from the latest research papers, from home!

Everyone can now prompt an AI assistant for free. This has optimized knowledge search ever more.

On the other hand, AI is currently makingÂ businesses ruthlessly efficient at applying existing knowledge, which also means fewer people are needed to do those jobs.

However, current AI models still struggle to apply, synthesize, and adapt existing knowledge to create something genuinely new.

So, I would say that in an era of abundant existing knowledge, the ability to create new knowledge represents the real competitive edge.

The perceived value of those people pushing the boundaries of human knowledge must increase accordingly (e.g., researchers building foundational models, redefining computer vision, inventing the next generation of robotics, etc.) 

Companies should start valuing more the work of those pushing the limits of science.

As a former academic researcher, I see this as overdue recognition for the countless PhD students whoâ€™ve been grinding away for years in low-reward conditions.

Nature doesnâ€™t like imbalance. It always finds a way of evening things out.

Looking forward to witnessing this new era! ğŸ˜Š

Watched FranÃ§ois Collet's talk: "How We Get to AGI" tonight with great interest. He presented unique insights based on years of research creating scientific benchmarks for measuring AIâ€™s intelligence.

My takeaway:

"As long as we can easily come out with tasks that are easy for humans, but that AI canâ€™t figure out, we donâ€™t have AGI yet."

My notes:

ğŸ”¹ Fluid intelligence:
â¤·Â It doesnâ€™t emerge from pretraining and scaling GPT models.

ğŸ”¹ Test-Time Adaptation (TTA):
â¤·Â It has dramatically improved model capabilities, but itâ€™s still not AGI.

ğŸ”¹ What is intelligence, anyway? 
â¤·Â Intelligence is a process, not to be confused with "skill", which is the output of that process. So, intelligence is the ability to deal with new situations.

ğŸ”¹ What is AGI, then?
â¤·Â We shouldnâ€™t define AGI as a system that can perform 80% of economically valuable tasks. Instead, true AGI would be a system that can learn new skills efficiently and solve previously unseen problems.

In the end, Collet shares his current work on building a new kind of AI model capable of extrapolating NEW solutions using a â€œlibraryâ€ of previously discovered abstractions.

In his view, the ultimate goal of AGI isnâ€™t automation. Itâ€™s to accelerate scientific progress.

Overall, a remarkable talk by a brilliant scientist.

Data munging has a couple of levels to it â†“

Level 1 - Data Fits in Memory
â¤·Â  Store data locally
â¤·Â  Use Pandas/Polars for ETL
â¤·Â  Train models with scikit-learn, TensorFlow, or PyTorch

Level 2 - Distributed Production Systems
â¤·Â  Process live or streaming data
â¤·Â  Build distributed pipelines using PySpark/Dask
â¤·Â  Deploy models that retrain in batches

As a rule of thumb:

ğŸ‘‰ If your data fits in your laptopâ€™s RAM, you're still playing at Level 1.

The real world runs on logs, events, clickstreams, APIs, terabytes, and SLAs. Itâ€™s fragmented, noisy, and constantly in constant motion.

However, most data scientists donâ€™t actually work with real-world data. Bridging the gap between development and production requires a shift in mindset and tooling.

So, how to level up?

âœ… Learn distributed computing:
â¤·Â  Use PySpark, Dask, or SQL engines like BigQuery
â¤·Â  Operate with scale as the default assumption

âœ… Think like an engineer:
â¤·Â  Design DAGs. Build pipelines. Automate every step
â¤·Â  Treat the model as just one component in a larger system

âœ… Go beyond notebooks:
â¤·Â  Dockerize workflows. Orchestrate with Airflow or Prefect
â¤·Â  Integrate with CI/CD pipelines and monitoring

Again, true impact starts when we reach production. When our ML models meet the live, messy, massive, beautiful chaos of the real world.

posts.text:
I've watched the recent talk â€œSoftware in The Era of AIâ€ by Andrej Karpathy at Y Combinator many times now.

With 1M+ views on YT, itâ€™s one of the best #AI talks Iâ€™ve seen for a general audience.

In ~40 minutes, Andrej distills the current trajectory of AI in a way thatâ€™s clear, engaging, and inspiring.

I've recommended it to many friends, and now I find myself asking:
â¤·Â What makes this talk exceptional?
â¤·Â What can we learn from the speaker?

Hereâ€™s what I think makes it superb:
âœ“ He seems genuinely excited about the topic, positive, and has open body language.
âœ“ He shares personal work along the way (tweets, posts, photos, and anecdotes), building trust and authenticity.
âœ“ He speaks in 1st person, sharing opinions and reflections (â€œI thinkâ€¦â€), which makes it feel personal.
âœ“ He uses analogies and real-world examples constantly, e.g., when calling LLMs a new kind of OS.
âœ“ He structures his talk into clear sections, recapping each one to reinforce key ideas.
âœ“ His slides alternate between big, bold visuals and simple, centered headlines.
âœ“ Most importantly, his tone stays hopeful throughout. Even when discussing limitations, he keeps the vibe optimistic.

Below is a more detailed breakdown of his flow â†“

Intro:
â€¢ Begins with enthusiasm and gratitude for being there.
â€¢ Remarks on the title and explains why the topic matters.
â€¢ Frames the big question: Why is software changing so fast?
â€¢ Provides a historical perspective: Software 1.0 â†’ 2.0 â†’ 3.0.
â€¢ Uses concrete examples to highlight his key observation.

Part 1: Software Evolution
â€¢ Quotes Andrew Ng: AI is the new electricity.
â€¢ Explains the analogy with real-life examples (e.g., factories â†’ software).
â€¢ Adds his twist: "LLMs are like a new OS."
â€¢ Introduces a counterintuitive idea: We have a new magical computer helping us boil eggs.
â€¢ Summarizes Part 1 with bullet points.

Part 2: The Psychology of LLMs
â€¢ Dives a bit into the internals of LLMs (transformers).
â€¢ Acknowledges their current limitations.
â€¢ Recommends sci-fi movies as a gift to the audience.
â€¢ Summarizes Part 2 with images.

Part 3: New Opportunities
â€¢ Offers a new abstraction: LLMs as the GUIs for machine intelligence.
â€¢ Gives real examples of current successes (e.g., Cursor).
â€¢ Poses the big question: What will future apps look like?
â€¢ Weaves analogies and personal stories (how he uses LLMs, how he â€œkeeps AI on a leash,â€ his first Waymo ride, etc).
â€¢ Shows an emotional video of kids vibe coding (going emotional with a hopeful vision).
â€¢ Ends Part 3 with his vibe-coded app experiments and areas still unexplored (this opens up for the next final section)

Part 4: Building for Agents
â€¢ Makes a bold prediction: Weâ€™re entering a new era of digital â€œagents.â€
â€¢ Imagines future humanâ€“AI interaction.
â€¢ Introduces upcoming tools and possibilities.

Final Summary:
â€¢ Displays a collage of key slides tying everything together into a single storyline.

Overall, an extremely well-packaged talk âœ¨
Should we try to replicate this framework?

There was a time when I believed I just needed to push myself harder. Grind longer. Power through the fatigue.

All I needed, I thought, was â€œjust one more research paper,â€ â€œjust one more OSS project,â€ â€œjust one more thing to prove to myself,â€ and so onâ€¦

This kind of self-pressure often drained me, but I was younger and could afford the late nights.

Today, I need to be more mindful of my capacity.

Iâ€™ve learned that willpower isnâ€™t an infinite resource, and that the best long-term strategy is to dose it wisely.

Motivation doesnâ€™t fail because weâ€™re weak. It fails because it runs out. 

Just like a muscle, our willpower gets depleted after use, and pretending it doesnâ€™t only makes the crash harder.

And if you feel like me, most of the time the problem isnâ€™t actually depletion, itâ€™s refusing to refuel.

Energy is a limited resource that can easily be drained.

Looking into it, I found a 2008 study that showed people who rested just 10 minutes between demanding tasks recovered completely, while others stayed depleted.

So the next time you canâ€™t focus, procrastinate, or lose control, donâ€™t shame yourself. 

Your tank could be empty. What you need isnâ€™t more discipline. You need a break that actually refuels you.

Relaxing isnâ€™t the same as cheering up. Itâ€™s not about just â€œfeeling goodâ€, itâ€™s about slowing down. 

Stop thinking
No cellphone
Quiet
Stillness
Doing nothing on purpose

So, Iâ€™ve stopped blaming myself when Iâ€™m drained.

Every time Iâ€™m exhausted, I tell myself:Â â€œRunning on empty doesnâ€™t make you strong, it actually makes you stuck.â€

Youâ€™ll never hit rock bottom again if you learn to pause before the crash ğŸ§˜

posts.text:
The real risk with AI is not that it sometimes produces wrong outputs. Itâ€™s that we still donâ€™t know when (or where) it will.

In 2023, researchers from Harvard University, MIT Professional Education, The Wharton School, and Boston Consulting Group (BCG) ran experiments with 758 consultants using GPTâ€‘4 and identified an invisible boundary.

They called it the "Jagged Frontier". The inability of LLMs to deal the same way with tasks with the same level of complexity for a human. 

What did they found?

When tasks matched GPTâ€‘4â€™s strengths:
âœ… +40% in quality, +25% faster execution, +12% more output

But when tasks didnâ€™t:
âŒ A 19% drop in efficiency 

Fair enough :/ But what's the real issue?

The problem is that most people couldnâ€™t tell when theyâ€™d crossed the line:

ğŸ‘‰ â€œOn some tasks AI is immensely powerful, and on others it fails completely or subtly. And unless you use AI a lot, you wonâ€™t know which is which.â€

Okay, that was 2 years ago. Todayâ€¦

AI systems are adapting: adding guardrails, evals, decision triggers, and human oversight.

The frontier is beginning to blur, not because LLMs are flawless, but because our systems for working with them are getting better.

Weâ€™re entering a new agentic phase by:

âœ“ Mapping workflows â†’Â e.g., aligning AI strengths with task complexity
âœ“ Building guardrails â†’Â e.g., audit trails, explainable outputs, confidence thresholds
âœ“ Upskilling humans â†’Â e.g., at prompt design, uncertainty detection, human-in-the-loop orchestration

I believe there is great potential in having models that know when to pause, ask, and let humans decide, completely flattering the line. 

Ask yourself:
Where are the jagged edges in your current workflow?

Tbh, it's getting harder for me to figure this one out ğŸ˜„

posts.text:
ML projects donâ€™t fail because models are wrong, they fail because the training data is unreliable.

In my experience, unreliable data pipelines are the fastest way to destroy trust in our work.

Thatâ€™s why determinism and idempotence in data transformation pipelines arenâ€™t â€œnice-to-haves.â€ Theyâ€™re our first line of defense!

Determinism:
â†³ same input data, same output - every single time.

Idempotence:
â†³ run the same operation once or 100x - result doesnâ€™t change.

So, how to get both of them?

Start here:

âœ… Make every transformation deterministic
â†’ No randomness without fixed seeds
â†’ No reliance on timestamps or implicit environment state
â†’ No third-party data without versioning

âœ… Make every job idempotent
â†’ Safe to re-run without side effects
â†’ Always overwrite outputs, never append blindly
â†’ Use unique, content-based identifiers for deduplication

âœ… Test like credibility depends on it (because it does)
â†’ Compare outputs over time
â†’ Add pipeline-level regression tests
â†’ Monitor for unexpected failures

Determinism + Idempotence = No+ğŸ‘»

posts.text:
Have you ever had that awkward moment, just after jumping into a new large codebase, when you find everything wild and chaotic?

I know, itâ€™s hard to avoid thinking: â€œThis is a mess. How could anyone maintain this stuff?â€

If youâ€™ve been into software long enough, Iâ€™m 100% sure youâ€™ve had this kind of feeling.

But over time, Iâ€™ve learned something:

â†³ When really complex systems work for real customers, even if they work imperfectly, thatâ€™s not something to take lightly.

The very fact that it has worked and survived the test of time is a huge achievement!

Because complex systems are always messy from the inside out.

SIDE NOTE: You know what I mean, the complexity of software is such a fascinating thing, isnâ€™t it? ğŸ˜

This complexity is the price we pay for solving real problems at scale.

Thereâ€™s no way to escape from it.

We donâ€™t eliminate complexity, we just move it around and hide it with abstractions. 

Thatâ€™s why I hesitate before touching legacy code that has quietly done its job for years.

Now I only change old, battle-proven code when I absolutely must. Seriously.

If you're in doubt, remember Chestertonâ€™s Fence: 

â†³ â€œDonâ€™t tear down a fence until you understand why it was built.â€

In other words: â€œDonâ€™t change what you donâ€™t understand!â€

I know it's hard this days, with #AI tools, itâ€™s easier than ever to refactor or rewrite code. The bar to start making changes has lowered down significantly. But thereâ€™s a danger in how quickly we forget why something exists. For example, AI doesnâ€™t know that a function was built around a legal constraint, a performance hack, or a hard-learned production failure.

Many disasters in software donâ€™t come from bad intentions. They come from lack of context and/or ignoring history.

New leaders often arrive, find things â€œuselessâ€ or â€œbroken,â€ and want to delete or change them without appreciating the journey it took other devs to get there.

So when entering into a new codebase, respect wildlife like a nice guest in your neighbor's house. Because we wonâ€™t be able to fully grasp the intricacies of an ecosystem at the first glance, and thatâ€™s why we tread lightly.

Let me said it again, we should stop pretending complexity can be removed. I've seen so many failed attempts into this direction... I can't count.

Letâ€™s accept complexity, thatâ€™s all. 

Good engineers make sure they understand the past before trying to mess around with the present.

Letâ€™s respect wildlife, for our own survival! ğŸŸ

posts.text:
Many of us once read TAOCP and believed that coding and algorithms were a form of art that couldnâ€™t be automated.

But we were wrong.

What I once saw as a unique human craft is now the next target for assembly line automation.

Turns out that programming is just advanced pattern-matching, and #LLMs are extremely good at it.

#AI doesnâ€™t just generate code that runs, itâ€™s already getting better than most human developers when looking at code quality.

But Iâ€™m not disillusioned about the future of software engineering, Iâ€™m just waking up to the shiftâ€¦

Because this isnâ€™t just another bump in abstraction, like when we moved from assembly to higher-level PLs, I think itâ€™s a paradigm shift.

Weâ€™re no longer writing most code from scratch, and if you still see yourself as a â€œcode writer,â€ youâ€™ll be left behind.

I believe the true winners in this new era will be those who understand how software should work, not just how to â€œmake it work once.â€

Because writing code isnâ€™t the hard part anymore. That problem has been effectively solved, much like how machine translation was solved with Transformers.

Now, the real challenge is:
â†’ Know what to build.
â†’ Know how it should work.
â†’ Know how to make it evolve.

For example, I can prompt an LLM to write code that ingests messages from a Kafka topic and stores them in a PostgreSQL DB.

But I still need to:
â†’ Handle message deduplication and idempotency.
â†’ Implement retries with exponential backoff on database failures.
â†’ Design the storage schema to accommodate evolving message formats.

Clear thinking about design, data, performance, and maintenance is becoming the most valuable skill in tech.

So no, Iâ€™m not walking away from code.

Iâ€™m doubling down on software design, distributed systems, and everything that makes software robust, maintainable, and scalable.

Cause if we know what we're doing, AI won't replace us, it'll just make us 100x more valuable.

posts.text:
I love knobs, buttons, and PBT keycaps.
Thereâ€™s something deeply satisfying about that tactile feedback, ... like my fingers are really feeling the machines. 

But two decades ago, we started replacing our lovely physical UX by something else (thanks, Apple for the iPhone). 
Everything shifted to flat, glowing digital keyboards in the name of "productivity," "more features," and "more screen space."

Now these screens are everywhere, even where it doesn't make any sense.
Touchscreens on fridges, on my front door, on cars (thanks, Tesla). 
Even TVs have on-screen keyboards?!

Oh, I have to mention my Samsung TV here.
It forces me to search using a remote with no physical letters that only moves in four directionsâ€¦ typing one letter at a time ğŸ¤¦â€â™‚ï¸

But now #AI has arrived, finally.
#LLMs promise to change everything.
And the industry now wants to replace the digital keyboard with voice.

But sure, weâ€™ve heard this before: Siri, Alexa, Google Home. Do you remember?
They never really took off.

So is natural language finally the future of UX?

Honestlyâ€¦ I donâ€™t think so.

Why?

Because it's inefficient, limited, and inconvenient.

â†’Â Itâ€™s inefficient because we think at thousands of words per minute but can only speak ~150. And unlike typing, you canâ€™t easily go back and edit your words when speaking. That makes natural language interactions slow, error-prone, and frustrating.

â†’Â Itâ€™s limited because it's lossy and ambiguous. Structured commands are clear. Language is fuzzy. You say one thing, the machine hears another. And you enter a cycle of clarifications.

â†’Â Itâ€™s inconvenient because saying â€œOpen a new tabâ€ out loud when âŒ˜T does it instantly is nonsense. Not to mention that this doesn't work in public spaces. 

So no, #LLMs wonâ€™t replace the mouse and keyboard.
It doesn't matter how good the models will get.

When weâ€™ll ditch them?
If you ask me, I think that'll happen when #AI can finally read our thoughts.

But thatâ€™s another story.

For now, Iâ€™ll keep enjoying the satisfying clack clack of my hand-modded mechanical keyboard âŒ¨ï¸

posts.text:
Let me tell you a quick story about programming, chess, and what's been wrong with coding interviews for decades:

In my 1st year of grad school, I heard about programming contests. They sounded exciting, but I didnâ€™t solved any problem (I didn't know how to code in 2009).

By 2nd year, I jumped in, competed in a local ACM-ICPC tournament and got hooked.

Next year, I was solving problem after problem on online judges (got 1,000+ correct submissions) and went to the regionals. It felt like leveling up in a video game.

But something changed.

The deeper I went, the more I realized: this wasnâ€™t fun anymore. It was like ches: to really excel, you have to dedicate your life to it (I love chess, btw). 

That killed the joy.

So I stepped away.

Years later, I entered the job market, and boom! Coding interviews (especially in big tech) were all about solving those kinds of ADA problems live, under extreme pressure.

It felt familiar. Too familiarâ€¦

But in this case there's a huge problem:

Solving algorithm puzzles in 45 mins has nothing to do with writing clean, maintainable software in the real world.

Worse, the system is really broken:

â†³ It rewards people whoâ€™ve memorized patterns, not those who solve real problems.
â†³ It filters out brilliant engineers who havenâ€™t â€œLeetcoded enough.â€
â†³ It creates a test thatâ€™s easy to fail.

I understand that this test style is scalable, but I've seen senior engineers with PhDs and successful OSS projects spending weeks practicing LeetCode problems just to get past the first interview screen.

Putting that much energy into riddles wasnâ€™t that bad 20 years ago. But the world has changed a lot since then.

Todayâ€™s #LLMs can solve most ACM-ICPC problems in seconds.

I don't really see how this could be a good way to test the value of professionals.

Today I read about undetectable apps that feeds GPT-powered answers during LeetCode-style online interviews, like the one created by Roy Lee.

So the system will collapse under its own weight (at least for its online mode). But honestly... I'm happy about it.

Itâ€™s finally time to kill programming-contest-style interviews for good.

So what should we do instead?

Here are some alternatives that I believe actually reflect real skills:

â†³ Give a real-world business problem. Ask the candidate to design and implement a solution from scratch. Discuss trade-offs, architecture, and impact.
â†³ Show messy, buggy, insecure code. Ask whatâ€™s wrong, whatâ€™s risky, and how theyâ€™d fix it.
â†³ Give raw data. Ask them to build something that adds or creates business value.

The whole point should be to simulate the real job. Because the real job lives in the real world. And in the real world, there is #AI, whether we want it or not.

So, letâ€™s stop testing people on fantasy skills.

If you have a different idea, let me know ğŸ™‚

P.S. I wrote a blog post many years ago about how I trained for ACM-ICPC contests (LLMs didnâ€™t exist back then), here's it â†’Â https://lnkd.in/dqhBvVEh

posts.text:
How can a large company like SEB foster innovation?

That was the question that my colleague Georg Schuppe addressed yesterday in the session: â€œSEBx: Innovate Beyond the Future.â€

I  very much agree with his vision: We need to be OK with trying new things and failing. 

The blockers to innovation are common to all big companies:
â†³ Employees drowning in repetitive tasks.
â†³ Managers too busy to make it a priority.
â†³ Data locked behind inaccessible databases.
â†³ Brilliant ideas crushed by silence, slow decisions, or KPIs.

The result?
â†³ Stagnation wrapped in legacy systems.
â†³ Big dreams with no budget.
â†³ â€œAgileâ€ in name only.

So how to break it out?

I think we need to understand that innovation isnâ€™t a fuzzy buzzword.

Itâ€™s a system!

And systems must scale if designed correctly. 

McKinsey & Company describes innovation based on three horizons:

1. Core (Incremental change):
â†³ Defend and extend what already works.
â†³ For example, to create internal tools, automate existing processes, or make small improvements.

2. Emerging (Disruptive change):
â†³ Build whatâ€™s next.
â†³ For example, SEB Embedded came from the idea of banking as a service, which wasnâ€™t such a cool idea 10 years ago, it was a bet that paid off.

3. Future (Transformational change):
â†³ Invent the unthinkable.
â†³ For example, 5 years ago, a superintelligent AI assistant in your pocket felt like sci-fi, today it is transforming multiple industries. 

So...

To unlock Core innovation:
â†³ Give people time and basic resources.
â†³ Let them fix whatâ€™s broken in their daily work.
â†³ And reward those who dare to care.

To foster Emerging innovation:
â†³ Create a multidisciplinary ecosystem of experts.
â†³ Give them support from the business to prototype, test, and implement innovative concepts swiftly and effectively.
â†³ Let them move fast, fail publicly, and try again.

To pursue Future innovation:
â†³ Fund the long game.
â†³ Protect wild ideas from quarterly goals.
â†³ Empower your visionaries, not only to deliver, but also to dream.

Becauseâ€¦

The future doesnâ€™t wait for a greenlight from leadership. It arrives, whether youâ€™re ready or not.

So here's a question for you:

Does your company has built an innovation system? 

If yes, ğŸ‘

Iâ€™ve heard a lot of hype about the new ChatGPT-4o image generation model, so I decided to test it with one simple task:

"To remove the green background from an uploaded close-up picture of mine and replace it with a pure black background."

Thatâ€™s it. No fancy edits. Just background removal.

I tried multiple prompts. Tweaked the wording. Iterated many times on the pictures asking to only change the background, and repeated the process.

Every result failed.

Why?

Because the generated images didnâ€™t look like me.

The differences were subtle: slightly off eyes, jawline, weird teeth, or unreal skin tone. Yet, they were enough to break the illusion (down below is the best result I got ğŸ‘‡).

Hereâ€™s the problem: the model has never seen me before.

Unless youâ€™re a public figure, an actor, a politician, or someone with a massive online presence (i.e., online pictures) these models can only guess.

So, the current limitations of current AI models aren't the models themselves. Itâ€™s the training data!

So, the next time you deploy a #GenAI solution in production, remember this:

Without the right data, even the smartest model could fly blind ğŸ™ˆ

Today, I attended the dbt Labs meetup at Solita's office in Stockholm. Hereâ€™s a key insight I took away:

The "semantic layer" is a big deal for both businesses and developers.

Johan Baltzar shared his journey as a Data Engineer in Spotifyâ€™s early days and how a deep understanding of the semantic layer played a crucial role in helping the Swedish ğŸ¦„ scale from A to B (as shown in the pictures â‡£).

What is the semantic layer? (just in case you wonder)

Itâ€™s a logical abstraction that translates raw data structures (tables, columns, schemas) into user-friendly, meaningful business terms.

For example, imagine two departments independently calculating revenue. Without a semantic layer, they could report wildly different numbers, both technically correct but confusingly inconsistent. A semantic layer ensures everyone speaks the same language from the start, providing a single, trustworthy definition for terms like "revenue".

Modern data stacks increasingly rely on semantic layers to democratize data analytics. Looker, Tableau, PowerBI.bg, and dbt Labs all offer semantic-layer capabilities, making it a hot topic in the business world!

Thanks to the organizers, I'm looking forward to the next dbt Labs event. ğŸ¥‚

posts.text:
I don't think we need Scala anymore, the language is doomed and will disappear.

For context, Scala gained popularity only for these two reasons:

1ï¸âƒ£ It introduced functional programming features that Java lacked at the time.

2ï¸âƒ£ The rise of Spark, a big data framework natively written in Scala.

However, with Javaâ€™s evolution (especially since Java 8, which introduced lambdas and streams) and #Python's dominance in Data Science, Scala is no longer necessary.

The entire ML/AI ecosystem is built around Python now (NumPy, Pandas, TensorFlow, PyTorch, Scikit-learn, etc.). Furthermore, PySpark is good enough for most use cases (even Databricks heavily supports Python for ML workloads).

#Java has caught up, especially with Project Loom and its upcoming features, and any companies that previously used Scala for microservices (e.g., Twitter/X) migrated back to Java or Kotlin.

Moreover, I find Scala cumbersome to learn as a programming language. It's a mix of object-oriented and functional paradigms, and the syntax is not very intuitive (although this might be personal preference).

So, why does Scala still exist?

First, some companies (especially in finance, big data, and ad-tech) have large Scala-based Spark codebases.

Second, Python APIs (like PySpark) introduce some overhead, as Python needs to communicate with the JVM (via Py4J), which can be a bottleneck in some cases.

Finally, if you enjoy functional programming paradigms (e.g., higher-order functions, pattern matching, and monads), Scala still does them slightly better than Java.

So, I strongly believe that learning Scala isn't worth it unless your company uses Spark, of course. But if you're mainly doing AI or ML, it's better to focus on Python instead.

Finally, a question for you:

Do you still use Scala, seriously?

I just read the latest blog post by Sean Goedecke. He wrote about what Iâ€™ve been thinking about for a while: â€œThe good times in tech are over.â€

I mostly agree. The job market in tech didnâ€™t make any sense. We used to live in a Nirvana.

We all know that. For years, software engineers were untouchable: high salaries, lavish perks, job security, etc.

I personally never felt good about this situation, as I couldnâ€™t understand how it was possible that seasoned school teachers earned less than junior software engineers.

Now weâ€™re seeing more and more layoffs in the tech sector and definitely not the same level of security as before.

Why?

Because cheap money fueled the tech boom in the 2010s. Companies could afford anything: mass hirings, paying ridiculous salaries, and even maintaining open-source projects. Profitability didnâ€™t matter much when money flowed the way it did.

Then interest rates spiked. Less money from investors, and the game changed.

The hard truth is thay most tech companies never really cared about open source or sustainability. They were just indulgences for devs in an era of excess.

Now, job security depends on one thing: delivering value that is connected to whatever your company cares about the most.

But thereâ€™s nothing special about this. In fact, this is how businesses operate in the real world. What was actually special was the previous job market situation.

Besides, I think the rise of AI has definitely aggravated this. And for now, itâ€™s merely the expectation of such an impact that causes companies to hire more cautiously.

Regarding AI, hereâ€™s what I think we should focus on in order to remain appreciated:

ğŸ”¹ Move efforts to where actual value is created (the specific business value is often the hardest part to automate with AI).

ğŸ”¹ Embrace AI, and even better, advocate for it (such a huge and rare opportunity to become an innovator).

ğŸ”¹ Accept the reality that AI isnâ€™t going anywhere and that the good old times are over (things arenâ€™t going to be as they used to be).

Letâ€™s see how it goes because maybe this is just the beginning of another golden age that we still havenâ€™t understood.

Who knows? ğŸ¤·

posts.text:
Lately, Iâ€™ve started worrying that I might be losing my ability to write complete apps from scratch.

Why?

Because the more I rely on AI coding assistants, the less I actually code myself.

Hereâ€™s how coding used to be:

Create a file â†’ set up imports and structure â†’ write functions â†’ add logic â†’ something doesn't work â†’ debug â†’ Google the issue â†’ find a fix â†’ write tests â†’ refactor â†’ repeat

Hereâ€™s how it works now:

Ask an AI to generate the code â†’ review â†’ tweak logic in natural language â†’ fix minor issues myself, if any â†’ ask AI to fix major ones â†’ repeat

Do you see the difference?

I no longer write the code from scratch anymore, an AI does it for me!

Iâ€™ve measured my productivity and thereâ€™s no question: I get more done with AI. It allows me to scaffold features in minutes, complete with tests and documentation, things that used to take hours before ğŸ¤¯

But hereâ€™s my concernâ€¦

What about the new generation of developers?

For them, writing code from scratch will feel as outdated as handwriting for everything today. And just like handwriting, the craftsmanship of coding is doomed to fade (not completely, but significantly).

Think about it. A century ago, handwriting was such a crucial skill, people took pride in their calligraphy. Today, "writing" no longer means putting words with a pen on paper, now itâ€™s about structuring readable ideas in a digital format.

The same shift is happening in coding. The act of "writing code" will be automated. What will remain is the higher-order skill of thinking systematically in a way that could guide an AI to turn ideas into executable programs that deliver some sort of value.

So, a few questions before ending this rambling: 

Should we still teach coding the hard way (i.e., without AI) like we still teach handwriting in schools? Or will that just feel awkward and outdated? Are we gonna lose the ability to write code from scratch?

I donâ€™t know. Most of us donâ€™t hunt or gather for food anymore, but that doesn't make eating any less satisfying.

Isnâ€™t?

posts.text:
Iâ€™m totally convinced that career growth isnâ€™t about climbing a title ladder.

We tend to position ourselves within specific categories (e.g., developer, senior engineer, staff engineer, director, CEO, you name it), expecting to jump from one to another eventually.

But the real game isnâ€™t about titles at all, itâ€™s about conquering complexity.

Why?

Because the amount of value we can create is directly tied to the level of complexity at which we operate.

Hereâ€™s a simple heuristic for assessing where you are in our careers and how to reach the next level:

ğŸ”¹ First, youâ€™re told WHAT to do AND HOW to do it (e.g., junior engineer).
ğŸ”¹ Then, youâ€™re just told WHAT to do (e.g., senior engineer).
ğŸ”¹ Next, youâ€™re ASKED HOW to do it (e.g., staff engineer).
ğŸ”¹ Eventually, youâ€™ll be ASKED WHAT should be done (e.g., director).
ğŸ”¹ Finally, no one tells or asks you ANYTHING, youâ€™ll set the goals yourself (e.g., executive level).

Do you see it?

Each step you climb makes you less vulnerable because the amount of value you can deliver increases exponentially. And this happens because your capacity to handle more complexity increases. Low complexity â†’ staying at the bottom â†’ higher risk of being replaced.

So, our real career growth is actually shaped by the challenges we must conquer to climb the complexity ladder.

For example, hereâ€™s a roadmap for developers:

1ï¸âƒ£ First, we must master the art of managing complexity in code. We should learn algorithms, exploratory data analysis (EDA), software architecture, and so.

2ï¸âƒ£ Second, knowing how to code isnâ€™t enough. We must identify which problems are worth solving. The complexity here lies in navigating uncertainty and delivering real-world value.

3ï¸âƒ£ Third, we must make sense of chaos. Leaders at the highest levels donâ€™t just solve problems, they choose which problems matter. They craft narratives, shape strategies, and define purpose.

So, letâ€™s stop obsessing over titles. Instead, letâ€™s ask ourselves: "Which layer am I in, and what level of complexity am I ready to conquer next?â€

Thatâ€™s how real growth happens ğŸªœ

I just finished reading a recent paper that explores the potential of applying agentic workflows to financial services.

Itâ€™s very clear (to me) that traditional methods for handling financial assets will fall behind quite soon, given the huge advantages of AI-powered systems.

The current LLMs-based technology allows building specialized agents for almost every financial task. From feature engineering to model evaluation, these systems deliver the precision and resilience that traditional methods simply cannot.

Concretely, the paper focuses on two use cases for agentic AI systems:

1ï¸âƒ£ FINANCIAL MODELING: The agentic crew consists of a manager and multiple agents who perform specific tasks such as exploratory data analysis, feature engineering, model selection, hyperparameter tuning, model training, model evaluation, and writing documentation.

2ï¸âƒ£ MODEL RISK MANAGEMENT: The agentic  crew consists of a manager along with specialized agents who perform tasks such as checking compliance of modeling documentation, model replication, conceptual soundness, analysis of outcomes, and writing documentation.

The results show that AI agents can effectively collaborate to perform these complex tasks in real-time.

The agents were able to streamline the modeling workflow, carry out model risk management procedures on a trained model, and effectively manage dependencies as well as collaboration among other agents.

The novelty of these models is that they learn, adapt, and evolve by themselves. For example, they can detect fraud with unprecedented accuracy, approve credit with confidence, and manage portfolio risk with unmatched efficiency.

Eventually, there will be adaptive learning agents that continuously improve their performance through past interactions and the various feedback they receive. Are we about to reach the next frontier in financial modeling?

posts.text:
What's the actual difference between invention and innovation?

Invention â†’ Itâ€™s about creating something novel, perhaps ingenious, yet it doesnâ€™t imply anyone actually needs or wants it.

Innovation â†’ It occurs when an invention addresses real-world problems (e.g., when customers find that a product is actually usable).

Customer-centricity, therefore, acts as the catalyst, transforming abstract inventions into impactful innovations.

In the #AI field, I think we often celebrate inventions: new models with groundbreaking performance, papers that set benchmarks, or novel frameworks that speed up prototyping. Yet, true innovation occurs only when these powerful ideas and tools meet genuine user needs (i.e., when AI becomes customer-centric).

For example, the invention of #LLMs was impressive, but it became innovative only when products like ChatGPT made them accessible, intuitive, and impactful for millions of everyday users.

On the other hand, sometimes inventions are ahead of their time precisely because they're too customer-centric. They assume customer needs that don't yet exist or aren't yet understood (e.g., Microsoftâ€™s Clippy).

Today, I believe many AI startups fail because they're too "ahead of their users," disconnected from real-world needs. They're brilliant, but not relatable.

Itâ€™s the deliberate act of understanding and anticipating customer desires (and frustrations) the thing that transforms impressive AI inventions into powerful innovations.

Corollary â†’ Invention alone isn't enough.

It is the act of understanding users that actually turns inventions into impactful innovations. 

So letâ€™s keep creating new things with curiosity, but innovate with empathy and common sense. 

Wishing you a great weekend!Â ğŸ˜‰

Two years ago, I made a huge mistake in a job interview.

I was in the company's lobby, waiting for my turn. But my interviewer wasnâ€™t waiting for me there. I expected the interview to start at 15:00, and at 15:15, I asked the receptionist if I could somehow contact him.

So she called the interviewer. While waiting, I checked my phone, and my heart sank.

The interview was supposed to start at 14:00. For some reason, I thought it was at 15:00. Bang!

I was 1 hour late.

At that moment, I felt like a complete failure, but I was already there, and running away from trouble is not my thing.

The interviewer arrived at 15:30.

We shook hands, and he led me into a meeting room.

I didnâ€™t make excuses. I didnâ€™t try to justify it. I just apologized (a lot).

He simply said once: "Let's leave it behind."

That was it.

For the next 2 hours, I had one of the most engaging technical discussions of my life.

Looking back, I wonder: How often do we hold onto someone elseâ€™s mistake instead of letting it go?

How many times have I let frustration cloud my judgment when someone disappointed me?

That day, I learned something more valuable than any job offer: The ability to forgive and move on is a rare strength.

I didnâ€™t get the job in the end, but I walked away with a far greater and more valuable experience.

Leave the past behind. Give people grace. You never know what impact it might have.

posts.text:
Why is it impossible to compress all human knowledge into an AI model?

I could hardly imagine a world where every published book, every scientific discovery ever made, and every human thought is compressed into a single AI that knows EVERYTHING.

Nevertheless, it sounds like the ultimate achievement, right? 

But this type of data compression has fundamental limits, dictated by Kolmogorov complexity, Shannonâ€™s information theory, and the nature of knowledge.

Let's have a deeper look at these three limitations:

1ï¸âƒ£ The shortest possible description of any dataset is its Kolmogorov complexity. It represents the length of the smallest algorithm that can generate it. It is uncomputable in the general case, meaning no algorithm can determine the absolute shortest representation of arbitrary data.

Furthermore, some sequences have no algorithmically shorter description than themselves, they are incompressible. While much of human knowledge follows structured patterns, large portions contain chaotic unpredictability, making a truly lossless compression of everything fundamentally impossible.

2ï¸âƒ£ Shannonâ€™s information theory defines entropy as the minimum number of bits needed to optimally encode a message. High-entropy data has less redundancy and cannot be compressed beyond a fundamental limit.

The problem is that not all human knowledge is low-entropy. While structured facts can be compressed efficiently, much of what we call "knowledge" includes uncertainty, noise, ambiguity, and subjective interpretation. Some knowledge is inherently probabilistic, meaning it lacks a fully deterministic structure that allows for compression.

3ï¸âƒ£ Even if we could encode all knowledge at one moment, it would immediately become outdated. Knowledge is non-stationary, i.e., it is not a fixed dataset but an evolving process.

New discoveries invalidate old assumptions, cultural contexts shift, and scientific revolutions rewrite fundamental truths. A model that captures "everything" today will still fail to encapsulate what comes next.

So what?

AI models, no matter how advanced, function as approximate compression algorithms: identifying patterns, reducing complexity, and reconstructing knowledge efficiently. 

But as just discussed, compression is never perfect.

Something is always lost. And whatâ€™s lost might be the very essence of intelligence itself: intuition, serendipity, and the unforeseen connections that drive human creativity.

So, would it ever be possible to build a super-intelligent AI that encapsulates everything?

No.

And even though the latest AI models seem to be very competent (think of ChatGPT 4.5 and o1),... folks, letâ€™s not forget the fundamental limits of what is truly possible ğŸ§

posts.text:
I've always been fascinated by how months of computation and vast amounts of knowledge can be distilled into a single array of bytes that fits in memory.

In ML, a ton of data massaging work, terabytes of information, and countless hours of computation can fit into a single file (a.k.a. the trained model ready for deployment).

As a data scientist, my job often comes down to delivering this model file to be seamlessly integrated into an MLOps pipeline. Once delivered, the file could be loaded to perform inference on real-time and real-world data.

Whatâ€™s inside?

That file encodes what the model have  learned. The weights and biases that determine how it makes predictions. Combined with its architecture (in the case of neural networks) or parameters (for statistical models), this forms the brain of an AI system.

But this brain is actually patterns extracted from massive datasets, fine-tuned neural network weights, decision tree splits, and distilled knowledge from everything the model has learned. And yet, all of this is stored in a file formatted as .pth (PyTorch), .ckpt (TensorFlow), .h5 (Keras), or the novel .safetensors (Hugging Face).

Take these examples:

â€¢ An XGBoost model trained on millions of data points, with a limited number of trees and controlled depth, can fit into a few megabytes and make predictions in milliseconds.

â€¢ A computer vision model, trained on millions of images, can be optimized and quantized to run efficiently on a smartphone.

â€¢ A LLM like GPT-4, trained on trillions of words and distilled into a highly optimized terabytes model, can predict the next token with sub-second latency on high-performance hardware.

Every model file represents months of human effort: cleaning data, optimizing pipelines, running experiments, and fine-tuning parameters until itâ€™s ready for deployment.

Now my question is: 

Is it possible to digitally compress everything, inc. all the human knowledge?

The answer is (fortunately?) negative, and it's due to fundamental limits imposed by information theory, Kolmogorov complexity, and the nature of data entropy.

But thatâ€™s a topic for tomorrow's post ğŸ˜‰

posts.text:
The openness of LLM training data is already being exploited to inject harmful information into AI systems.

This practice is called â€œmodel poisoning,â€ and itâ€™s a growing threat âš ï¸

Todayâ€™s models could be easily compromised with false or misleading data, forever distorting the outputs they generate.

For example:

What do you think would happens if malicious actors flood popular forums with misleading political statements or fake news during election campaigns? Current LLMs "learn" from these false narratives and, in turn, generate biased or factually incorrect information that is hard to revert, perpetuating a misinformation cycle â™»ï¸

Here's how to prevent model poisoning:

âœ“ Curate and filter training data meticulously.
âœ“ Use anomaly detection to spot strange patterns.
âœ“ Apply techniques like differential privacy and adversarial training to strengthen models.
âœ“ Regularly audit and monitor models to detect any signs of poisoning.
âœ“ Limit data source access, rely on trusted datasets, and consider synthetic data.
âœ“ Collaborate with experts, share knowledge, and retrain models periodically to stay ahead.

The above techniques are a good start; however, as AI-generated content floods the internet, future models will inevitably be trained on it. Indeed, research shows that weâ€™re already running out of public high quality training data ğŸ¤¯ 

This could create an endless loop of AI generated data also used for training thatâ€™s harder to control.

Another big problem is data retention. If an already deleted piece of information was part of an LLM's training data, the model might still generate and share it, potentially exposing removed material. Meaning everything you put online will be "remembered" by an AI model, whether you want it or not.

So, the question is:

How do we ensure models are trained from trustful data sources and forget harmful information theyâ€™ve learned?

These are an open research questions that I find very interesting, and itâ€™s not just about preventing â€œmodel poisoning.â€ Itâ€™s about preserving the integrity of the entire AI ecosystem.

We need to solve these kind of issues before the whole system completely swallows itself â³

posts.text:
Want to quickly estimate how long it takes for an investment to double in value?

You donâ€™t need a calculator. The "Rule of 72" is a quick mental math hack that gives you the answer. This simple formula (derived from the logarithmic formula for compound interest) lets you estimate how long itâ€™ll take for an investment to reach 2x its value, based on a fixed annual return.

Hereâ€™s how it works:

Years to Double = 72 / rate of return (r)

Thatâ€™s it. Just one number to keep in mind.

For example, if your investment grows at 8% per year, it will take:

72 / 8 = 9 years to reach 2x its value

Here's why I use the Rule of 72:

â†’ Quick mental math to estimate returns for interest rates between 6% and 10%.
â†’ Works for inflation, population growth, and investment returns.
â†’ Simple but powerful trick for quick financial decisions.

ğŸŒŸ Pro tip: For rates under 6%, use 69 instead of 72 for more accuracy. For rates over 10%, use 75 to get closer to the truth.

How are the hyperparameters of LLMs fine-tuned without blowing up already massive budgets? ğŸ’°

As we know, when training "small" ML models, we can afford to test different hyperparameters repeatedly, tweaking them until we get the best results. But with LLMs? Thereâ€™s usually only one shot at training.

So, I just went deep into different hyperparameter tuning techniques for LLMs and discovered the concept of "scaling extrapolation."

In essence, itâ€™s the process of predicting which hyperparameters will work best on large models based on testing smaller ones. Scaling extrapolation is crucial because training large models is a massive resource drain, and we just canâ€™t afford to mess around with endless combinations.

Why does it works?

Empirical research has shown that many optimal hyperparameters remain stable when model size changes. For example, a 2022 paper from researchers at Microsoft and OpenAI demonstrated that it is possible to transfer hyperparameters from a 40M model to a 6.7B model: ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dY3Ef6Vk

Interestingly, scaling extrapolation is still a niche field, tackled by only a few experts.

Why?

Because itâ€™s incredibly complex. If we have just 10 hyperparameters, weâ€™re already looking at over 1,000 combinations to test. The complexity explodes as more hyperparameters interact with each other.

I find this challenge fascinating.

For now, itâ€™s very unlikely that will be working on training large models at this scale. However, what seemed large two years ago is considered small today. Staying ahead means knowing about techniques (like scaling extrapolation) before they become essential. This is how we break through.

Want to dive deeper into scaling extrapolation? Check out this insightful blog post: ğŸ”— https://lnkd.in/dhMctqYc by luke metz.

Thereâ€™s no doubt: hyperparameter tuning has already reached the next level ğŸš€

Can current AI models really make money as a freelance software developer?

Researchers at OpenAI just tackled the million-dollar question, literally ğŸ’µ

Their latest research introduces SWE-Lancer, a benchmark built from 1,488 real freelance software engineering tasks on Upwork, collectively worth $1 million in payouts.

Unlike previous benchmarks that rely on unit tests, SWE-Lancer evaluates AI like a real hiring manager would, i.e., by grading tasks with full end-to-end tests, triple-verified by senior engineers.

This is the first benchmark to map AI coding performance to actual $$$ earned. It includes everything from $50 bug fixes to $32,000 full-stack feature builds, covering web, mobile, APIs, and cross-codebase interactions.

The initial benchmark results? 

Well... the paper claims that AI still falls short, but I believe the results are already quite impressive.

The best model, Claude 3.5 Sonnet, managed to earn $208,050 out of a possible $500,800 in the SWE-Lancer Diamond subset. On the full dataset, it scraped together $400,000 out of $1 million. Of course, still not quite there yet to fully replacing human engineers, but already BIG if we consider itâ€™s just the beginning.

Whatâ€™s next?

AI-assisted software development will reshape the job market (without any doubt) especially for freelancers and junior engineers (as stated in the â€œImpact Statementâ€ section 7 in the paper). However, we're still far from having fully autonomous AI engineers. More importantly, AI-generated code also comes with serious risks. For example, security vulnerabilities, bad architecture, and potential model autonomy concerns.

Nevertheless, the road to fully autonomous AI-driven software engineering could be shorter than we think! ğŸ¤–

This may sound like a truism, but over time, Iâ€™ve realized that itâ€™s 1,000x easier to tell others what needs to be done than to actually do the thing.

They seemed to know better than I what the â€œobviousâ€ next step was. However, I was the one who had to do the hard work: write the code, run the experiments, write the paperâ€¦ (the list goes on).

Throughout our lives, there are always people around us who seem to know what we need to do: first our parents, then friends, colleagues, and managers at work. This doesnâ€™t necessarily make things easier, even though it may create the illusion that it does.

Because hereâ€™s the thing: today, step-by-step guides exist for almost any â€œhardâ€ problem. But having a roadmap doesnâ€™t mean reaching the destination.

Today, with super-powerful AIs in our pockets, we all have access to artificial agents that can quickly list the steps needed to solve difficult problems. Yet, most of us still donâ€™t succeed at it. Why? I believe itâ€™s because of time. We need time to prepare, plan, and execute everything!

posts.text:
Foundational models have radically changed the way we build and ship AI apps these days.

In traditional ML, we start by gathering DATA, move on to training and evaluating a MODEL, and only then (and depending on the results) is that we focus on enhancing the PRODUCT. This approach has its merits, e.g., we can fine-tune the model to meet our specific needs and ensure that the data is good enough before launching. However, with pre-trained models already available, this process is painfully slow and inefficient. Why? Because we could spend weeks or months gathering the right data and fine-tuning our model(s)... while the product remains in a constant flux.

Thankfully, we donâ€™t need to follow that path anymore.

When building on top of foundational models, instead of getting stuck in endless data wrangling, we can start by building the product with AI-generated data and see if it works for a pilot number of users. Once weâ€™ve got something promising, we can do real data and model optimizations. 

I find this shift a game-changer!

It isnâ€™t about creating better user interfaces powered by AI, itâ€™s about getting the product to market faster. And that means we can start understanding real user needs much earlier, adapt quickly, and iterate faster.

For example, imagine youâ€™re developing a new app aimed at helping small businesses manage their finances. Before, you would have spent months analyzing customer data, cleaning it, and fine-tuning a model. But then, after a while, you find out the users didnâ€™t actually want to reduce expenses, what they wanted was to better understand customers to maximize ROI instead. By leading with the product first, we could have launched an early version, gathered ROI feedback, and launched accordingly without waiting for Model v1.0 to be ready.

So, getting to market faster is a huge advantage. The quicker we get the feedback, the quicker we can adjust, and the better we can refine our offering to match what users ACTUALLY want, not just what we think they want ğŸ˜‰

We donâ€™t need perfect data, we need quicker insights. We can build, test, and adjust along the way.

Just start building, and let it go ğŸš€

The traditional computer science education system MUST change radically as AI becomes truly ubiquitous.

In the past... do you remember? It was all about having the right knowledge and  "programmer's mindset." We started by learning pseudocode, picking a language, and reading books that began with a bunch of syntax before diving deep into classical algorithms and data structures. Solving problems from scratch has been the pillar of traditional computer science education for a long time!

But today, all of this seems irrelevant to me. Why?

Because nearly every small coding problem I can think of has already been solved, and the unsolved ones are too big for me to solve alone. Furthermore, AI-powered coding assistants can generate high-quality code faster than I ever could. With a simple prompt, they can build entire applications, optimize algorithms, and refactor complex codebases.

So, do we still need to know the nitty-gritty details of syntax and classical algorithms?

Probably not.

â†’ Manually implementing a sorting algorithm? âŒ 

â†’ Understanding the nuances of pointer arithmetic in C? âŒ 

â†’ Memorizing syntax rules for multiple programming languages? âŒ 

So, what do we need instead?

â†’ The ability to ask the right QUESTIONS and EVALUATE AI-generated responses âœ…

These are the new technical skills that will define the future of learning (in almost every other field, I believe).

Our education system needs to shift accordingly. Instead of emphasizing rote memorization, we must cultivate a mindset of questioning EVERYTHING and rigorously verifying AI-generated answers.

The result of this upcoming educational transformation is uncertain.

Butâ€¦

I donâ€™t see any other way forward ğŸ¤”

P.S. Disagreement and discussion about this matter are welcome.

Game Development and AI Engineering have so much to learn from each other.

This was my take after attending Alexander Chatzizachariasâ€™ talk at Jfokus this year titled â€œWhat is Multimodal RAG, and Can You Build a Village with It?â€ It was a perfect mix of education and seemingly (absurd?) fun, inspiring anyone to explore the potential of multimodal RAG in the gaming industry.

For those unfamiliar, Multimodal Retrieval-Augmented Generation (MRAG) is the technique of combining your own textual, visual, and audio data to enrich prompts before theyâ€™re processed by GenAI. Imagine a user asks a question, and the system digs into a personalized data pool for context, and then through GenAI it delivers a coherent, relevant response.

We can use multimodal RAG in video games, and Iâ€™m particularly excited about MRAGâ€™s potential to create games that are both more engaging and intellectually stimulating.

Traditionally, Non-Player Characters (NPCs) rely on static, hardcoded responses. But with MRAG, we can make them dynamic, lifelike, and far more engaging to interact with. For example, we can build NPCs that not only respond intelligently but also interact with each other, pursue goals, and move dynamically within the game world (all powered by complex RAG workflows).

This is exactly what Alexander explored in his session, and itâ€™s a game-changer. He showed how much more fun it could be for gamers to interact with NPCs that are smart enough to search for and display multimedia assets. 

Two examples: 1ï¸âƒ£ an NPC finding and playing a metal song that matches the playerâ€™s mood in a specific game scenario, or 2ï¸âƒ£ interpreting the playerâ€™s own paintings in real-time.

Cool, huh?

posts.text:
My research work has just reached 700 citations on Google Scholar, and I would like to reflect on it.

7x100 might sound like a small number for seasoned researchers, but for me, itâ€™s a milestone. Why? Because it feels incredible to see that my work has made at least a tiny impact, being referenced by researchers worldwide.

Do citations matter?

Well, yesâ€¦ but maybe not in the way youâ€™d think.

Citations are often seen as a benchmark for research impact, but they don't tell the full story. They reflect how often a research paper is used as a foundation for further studies, but they donâ€™t necessarily measure the quality or depth of contributions. Some of the papers Iâ€™m most proud of have taken years to gain traction (e.g., my DepClean paper currently ranked 1st in my profile took 3 years to get traction), while other papers have got cited quickly due to trending topics or collaborative networks (e.g., my Data Mining in sports paper, ranked 2nd in my profile took me by surprise).

What have I learned about citations?

â†’ High-quality work, even if initially overlooked, will eventually get cited. The prestige of the journal or conference definitely plays a role, but solid research speaks for itself over time.

â†’ Co-authoring with researchers from different institutions or disciplines increases exposure, leading to more citations.

â†’ Even highly specialized research can gain significant attention if it addresses a critical gap or introduces a novel perspective.

For most researchers, the number of citations per year tends to grow linearly but eventually plateaus. I predict mine might actually decrease this year, as Iâ€™ve mostly stepped away from academia ğŸ˜ 

That said, Iâ€™m still open to academic research collaborations!

If youâ€™re working on something exciting and think we could collaborate, feel free to reach out ğŸ™‚

posts.text:
Documenting source code is a waste of time and space nowadays ğŸ—‘ï¸

I still remember the days when we were arguing about different documentation practices and paradigms. Then, tools like Doxygen, Javadoc, and Sphinx were created to FORCE us (lazy developers) to explain our code in an organized way using "templates." They extracted API signatures, methods, parameters, and more, transforming them into human-readable form, often in HTML or Markdown formats, so that our colleagues and future versions of ourselves could easily understand what the code was supposed to do.

But our battle tested doc tools are not very useful anymore.

Why?

Because current AI can generate good enough documentation automatically for us. For example, GitHub Copilot's chat can answer the â€œwhat it doesâ€ and the â€œhow it does itâ€ questions for any function (in milliseconds and with very high accuracy) ğŸ¤¯

So, code documentation has fallen into automation, becoming a commodity.

Indeed, I believe that most code documentation today is actually noise.

Think about it. Today, IDEs help us create meaningful variable names easily. They generate all kinds of templates. Typing is not what slows us down anymore: READING IS! The more code we have to read, the longer it takes to understand what needs to be changed in the codebase. So documentation becomes a waste of time in the eyes of efficient developers.

So, should all comments disappear?

The only scenario in which writing a comment makes sense to me is when we use it to add information about the â€œwhy this way.â€ For example, adding a comment when checking for the existence of a specific configuration file in a function to ensure that custom settings load correctly for various deployment environments. This kind of info adds more â€œcontextâ€ about why the code does what a prompted AI said it does (i.e., it reflects the human decision made along the way).

In essence, future documentation requires a narrative. Without it, you just wind up splatting unnecessary words on a codebase, rather than communicating anything useful to the other devs or their AI partners.

And yes, Iâ€™m sorry for the billions of lines of open-source comments and the many human hours invested in them (nothing wrong because they have helped build the AI models after all).

R.I.P. my dear Javadoc ğŸª¦

.

So, the big question is: which jobs will survive the AI wave?

No one knows for sure ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸ 

But there are already some existing tech roles that are at high risk of replacement:

âŒ Rutinary dev tasks â†’ AI-powered tools like GitHub Copilot and ChatGPT can now write boilerplate code, reducing the need for entry level devs who traditionally started their careers handling common and often repetitive coding tasks.

âŒ Low-level data analysis â†’ Many BI dashboards and AI assistants can now interpret trends, generate statistical reports, and more. These tools will sooner or later replace some junior data analyst roles.

âŒ Manual software testing â†’ Automated testing frameworks and AI-powered test generation are already replacing traditional QA roles focused on manual testing.

These are just 3 examples. Arguably, ALL coding jobs could be automated to some extent, posing a real risk to disrupt the dev job market.

One thing is certain: CHANGE is the only constant. If we keep doing the same thing for too long without evolving, our skills will eventually become obsolete.

The ONLY option is to move up the value chain, focusing on high-level problem-solving, creativity, and improving our collaboration with AI.

So letâ€™s keep learning. Keep sharing. Keep changing.

posts.text:
*Multitasking* doesnâ€™t work, we all know that. But really?

We live in a world where juggling many tasks is hard to avoid. We deal with a bombardment of real-time messaging threads, emails popping up, and online meetings, often all at once. What is worst, this kind of #multitasking is sometimes perceived as a sign of efficiency ğŸ¤¯

In this era of perpetual distraction, understanding the limits of our multitasking capabilities is crucial for optimizing work #performance. 

So, I looked into this topic and stumbled upon an interesting paper from 2011 that showed empirical evidence that multitasking can improve productivity, but only up to a certain point: ğŸ”—https://lnkd.in/gAvHFfXN

The paperâ€™s findings are pretty clear: medium multitaskers perform reasonably well when it comes to handling many computer-based multitasking tasks, while high multitaskers suffer from it. However, accuracy declines steadily with increased multitasking, no matter how much you juggle! ğŸ™„

â€œâ€¦juggling multiple tasks is much more difficult while balancing on a high wire, where performance mishaps can have serious consequences.â€

The results follow a classic inverted-U curve for productivity: multitasking helps until it doesn't. At first, switching between tasks boosts your mental alertness and efficiency. But after a certain point, switching too often leads to mental #overload, making it harder to maintain focus and accuracy on mid complexity tasks.

So, what does this mean for us in 2025? ğŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸

Over the last decade, weâ€™ve exponentially increased the number of information channels we juggle at work. Itâ€™s likely that many of us have BECOME high multitaskers in the process, without even noticing it.

To maintain both speed and accuracy, we should focus on fewer tasks at a time (ideally in sequence, without overlap). And if you ever feel overloaded, take a step back, evaluate your multitasking habits, and aim for that sweet spot where productivity is achieved without compromising #quality.

Seriously, too much multitasking can seriously compromise the quality of our work.

Itâ€™s all about balance and awareness ğŸ˜‰

*A common form of multitasking occurs when a user shifts attention to perform several independent but concurrent computer-based tasks.

Itâ€™s not about the latest models, expensive GPUs, or overpriced consultants. I think DATA is the only thing that truly matters!!!

Then, everything shifted toward Deep Learning thanks to the availability of powerful hardware. But I argue that one thing has remained unchanged: the need to process massive amounts of messy #data, and that this is the everlasting skill ğŸª„

Just as an example, the creators of DeepSeek shared their model architecture and its trained weights with the world as open-source. But whatâ€™s the one thing they kept completely secret? Their training data ğŸ¤”

So, if I could only master ONE skill, it wouldnâ€™t be tweaking models or fine-tuning hyperparameters. It would be handling data at #scale, i.e., building efficient pipelines, automating workflows, and ensuring data quality. This is a top 1% skill that will remain valuable for decades.

At a high level, there are three fundamental steps:

1ï¸âƒ£ Extracting data from its source
2ï¸âƒ£ Transforming and cleaning that data
3ï¸âƒ£ Delivering the cleaned data optimally to the right destination 

* This process is commonly known as ETL (Extract, Transform, Load).

And sure, building a simple ETL pipeline for an AI system isnâ€™t hard (most developers can build chatbots easily these days). But the real challenge lies in designing resilient, scalable, and fault-tolerant data systems that can handle ever-growing #complexity.

And thatâ€™s why our dear data engineers arenâ€™t going anywhere in the years to come ğŸ˜‰

I still remember the early days when I had nice train/test sets for evaluating my ML projects ğŸ“Š

Chip Huyen, author of the book "AI Engineering," shared her perspective on this topic recently:

"As AI systems grow more intelligent, evaluating them becomes exponentially harder. Unlike traditional ML, where you might verify whether an email is spam or not, todayâ€™s AI might summarize a book or write a poem. The result looks coherent, but is it accurate? Often, you need to dive deep to assess quality, making evaluation a silent yet formidable bottleneck."

As engineers, I think weâ€™ll spend much more time creating evaluation metrics that align technical performance with business impact, rather than fine-tuning parameters for our AI models.

AI testers will be in great demand in the near future.
