posts.text:
Have you ever had the feeling that something you believe should have already been researched and proven true? ğŸ¤”

This happens to me quite often.

And itâ€™s always #exciting to discover that some of our #intuitions have already been studied, named, and supported by scientific research. 

For example, today I discovered the concept of "prospective hindsight." The idea is that just by imagining that a project has already been completed (whether successfully or not) can enhance our ability to identify reasons for future outcomes.

This insight comes from an influential study by Deborah Mitchell, who explored this concept in her 1989 #paper titled "Back to the Future: Temporal Perspective in the Explanation of Events." The research found that using prospective hindsight can improve decision-making by up to 30%.

This is how it works: envision that the event youâ€™re planning has already taken place. Then ask yourself:

â†’ What made it succeed?
â†’ What caused it to fail?

I apply this technique when writing, as it allows me to uncover blind spots I didnâ€™t even realize existed. Not only does it force me to #confront hidden #assumptions and #anticipate potential #roadblocks, but it also clarifies the key factors that could propel the task forward. It saves time and resources while instilling clarity and confidence.

You can try it yourself right now. Ready? Hereâ€™s an experiment for you:

Imagine yourself celebrating your biggest success of 2025. Now ask yourself: What decisions, habits, or risks did you take to get there?

Done? Now take ACTION.

â€œThe future isnâ€™t something we passively stumble into. Itâ€™s built by the questions we dare to ask ourselves today.â€

What is DORA and why should we care about it?

The Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) is a game-changer for the financial industry in the EU. It came into effect last Friday, January 17th, 2025 (yes, politicians deploy on Fridays ğŸ¤¯). DORA pushes financial entities across the EU to meet stricter #standards to stay #resilient against #cyberattacks and ICT #disruptions. ğŸ’»âš¡

If you work in the FinTech sector, DORA is a big deal because:

ğŸ”’ It enforces robust risk management frameworks to protect systems from breaches and outages.
ğŸ“¢ It mandates that firms must report major ICT incidents quickly to tackle threats head-on.
ğŸ¯ Expect rigorous operational stress tests, including threat-led penetration testing.
ğŸ¤ Itâ€™s not just banks and financial firms; cloud providers and other ICT vendors must meet compliance too.

For financial institutions ğŸ¦, adapting to DORA is a massive #commitment, perhaps comparable in scale to MiFID and GDPR. A crucial part of this is identifying critical software functions and their dependencies on third-party vendors(ranging from tech giants to smaller SaaS providers). Aligning all these parties with DORA is challenging but necessary to ensure the availability of critical services, even in the face of large-scale cyberattacks.

For developers ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’», this means more job #opportunities in the financial industry and a growing demand for enhanced resilience into every software solution we build (i.e., setting stronger security protocols, seamless collaboration with risk teams, and designing systems that can handle critical disruptions in real time).

DORA is not just about compliance, it's a commitment, and a call to action to create a more secure financial ecosystem with operational resilience! ğŸš€

I believe most of the current #management #skills will become obsolete in the coming years.

The next wave of management books will likely focus on dealing with #AI #agents instead of humans (i.e., directing AI toward achieving desired outcomes with precision).

In fact, learning how to guide AI-powered systems is as important today as learning how to properly "Google search" was in the 2000s.

If I were a technical manager, hereâ€™s what I would start doing RIGHT NOW to prepare:

1ï¸âƒ£ Learn Prompt Engineering: Mastering the techniques to ask the right questions and designing inputs to maximize output value of AI tools (e.g., refining context, clarifying intent, and fostering creativity).

2ï¸âƒ£ Optimize Workflows: Experimenting with integrating AI tools into everyday processes. Identify where they can reduce workload or augment team's outputs (e.g., automating mundane tasks, enhancing decision-making, or streamlining communication workflows).

3ï¸âƒ£ Develop AI Literacy: Ensuring everyone in the team understands the fundamentals of how AI works and its current limitations.

I still hear some developers referring to #AI as a #threat.

While undeniably useful, current AI models have notable limitations in the context of software development.

Here are my 3 favorites:

1ï¸âƒ£ Lack of Contextual Understanding:Â AI lacks the domain expertise and intuition required to assess edge cases or fully grasp the implications of design decisions.

2ï¸âƒ£ Limited Creativity:Â While AI can recombine existing elements in unexpected ways, its â€œcreativityâ€ stems from probabilistic reasoning, not from subjective experience, intentionality, or insight.

3ï¸âƒ£ No Accountability:Â Software projects donâ€™t live in isolation, they exist to solve real-world problems. An engineer must account for business needs, user behavior, and technical feasibility, which requires human judgment and responsibility.

So, will AI replace software developers?

I don't think so (at least not anytime soon). But it is fundamentally changing the development landscape, making human creativity and problem-solving capabilities more essential than ever.

Adaptability is one of the most valuable human skills. As long as the world keeps changing, there will always be a need for people who can pivot quickly and come up with creative solutions to the most challenging problems.

Itâ€™s winter now â„ï¸. I wrote a blog post on this topic during the summer last year ğŸŒ (link down below), and my thoughts remain unchanged.

Am I wrong?

posts.text:
Just before starting every new year, I do two exercises that help me  focus on whatâ€™s important and to achieve my personal goals:

1ï¸âƒ£ â€œWheel of Lifeâ€

I draw 3 lines intersecting at the center of an imaginary circle to divide it into 8 sections. Each line represents one of the following areas of life: money, family and friends, fun, career, personal growth, health, love, and giving.

I rate my satisfaction in each area on a visual scale by marking dots along the radius of each section. Then, I connect the dots to form a shape within the circle.

The resulting shape gives a visual representation of how "balanced" I feel in life. The parts of the shape that are uneven highlight areas where I should focus more attention to improve in the coming year.

I compare the current shape with the previous yearâ€™s shape and reflect on what has improved and what has declined during that time.

2ï¸âƒ£ â€œNew Year Goalsâ€

I start by revisiting the past yearâ€™s goals and thinking about new goals to improve the current status of my â€œWheel of Lifeâ€ (from exercise 1).

I divide a piece of paper into four quadrants, each representing a quarter of the coming year.

Then, I write no more than 4 goals in each quadrant, following the SMART framework (i.e., Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound).

For example, instead of writing â€œGetting X certification from Google,â€ I write â€œStudying 4 hours every week to get X certification from Google.â€

I have found that setting smaller goals that are achievable every 3 months works better for me than having bigger yearly goals. The reason is that one year is too much time, and I tend to forget the goals. I also need that dopamine hit that comes just after achieving each goal.

ğŸ†•Â in 2025, I want to try out the following 3 new productivity hacks:

- Daily focus log (i.e., write down the amount of time I actually focused during the day).

- Weekly review (i.e., spend 15 minutes every Sunday afternoon to look at the status of my quarter and review how it is going).

- Slowing down (i.e., relax more and lower down my expectations of what I can actually achieve during a short period of time). 

Footnote: Numerous studies have shown that writing these things on a piece of paper significantly increases the chances of achieving them.

PS: I you have kids, then you know what the drawings on the back are ğŸ˜„

posts.text:
Yesterday, I attended an insightful PyData Meetup in Stockholm, hosted by Solita. Very good discussions there, with highly skilled Data Scientists and hands-on community members.

Below my thoughts on the 2 talks of the day:

1ï¸âƒ£ "How LLMs work?" by Jonas Thunberg

â†’ Understanding embeddings is essential: LLMs use multi-head self-attention to determine which vector embedding aligns best in the vector space. This involves leveraging previous words' semantic (more embeddings!) to develop an abstract understanding of the textâ€™s meaning.

â†’ Matrices are everywhere: The fundamental math behind all this stuff is basic operations over matrices and in particular matrix multiplication (that's why GPUs are so expensive nowadays).

ğŸ¤” I have a question for companies:

â†’ Do you seek for experts who truly understand the intricate math behind these technologies, or do you prefer speed and practical skills for rapid deployment instead?

2ï¸âƒ£"Building RAG for Financial Data" by Dmitrii Shiriaev

â†’ RAG is probably the most applicable AI approach for companies at the moment. It requires "knowing" and applying many tricks to accurately extract insights from data to enhance search capabilities (e.g., parsing double-column PDFs, or decoding figures to answer specific business questions). So, it looks to me that "Data Scientist" are now turned into "Search Scientists".

â†’ The RAG community lacks open resources to learn the best tricks out there. We still have Kaggle for traditional ML knowledge sharing (e.g., for fine tuning models), but current RAG knowledge is mostly empirical, driven by hands-on experimentation with messy corporate internal data.

ğŸ¤” One thought on this:

â†’ Many companies are cautious about deploying RAG solutions directly to customers due to potential risks of losing credibility and prestige if some responses are wrong. Building trust in these technologies is still WIP. But we'll get there soon.

Have a great weekend folks!

PS: Many thanks to Sebastian WallkÃ¶tter, Ph.D. for arranging and coordinating the event.

Everywhere, I see computer scientists that look like they are working on the right thing ğŸ¤”

I wrote a blog post reflecting on his ideas through the lens of someone who has experienced the pressures of producing science "the modern way."

I attended a great BFSI after-work event this week at Amazon Web Services (AWS), hosted by Couchbase and Playground Data. There were top-notch presentations, demos, and a well-moderated Q&A session at the end (not to mention the fantastic boat trip across Stockholm's archipelago).

Here are 3 nuggets from the meta-discussion that I still remember:

1. Q: Is choosing a dedicated database always the best option?Â A: It's important to select a database that best fits the requirements of each specific use case. However, thereâ€™s always a trade-off regarding how much versatility is sacrificed in exchange for performance and vice versa.

2. Q: To what extent does it make sense for an organization to pursue a multi-cloud strategy? A: It enhances resilience, avoids vendor lock-in, and optimizes costs across various services. However, spreading resources across multiple clouds also increases complexity, requiring additional expertise and human talent to manage it effectively.

3. Q: What are proven ways to leverage AI as a key driver for tech transformation in the financial sector?Â A: AI has shown to be a workhorse in the sector, inc. predictive analytics, automating routine processes, and enhancing customer experiences through personalized services. However, itâ€™s not a silver bullet, particularly when it comes to building trust and ensuring the reliability of customer-facing services.

ğŸŒ The web is (arguably) the only tech platform that has been continuously transformed and evolved at a global scale over the last 30 years. How was this possible? What can we learn from the past technical mistakes and successes? 

My latest blog post addresses these questions, with a focus on the engineering paradigms that marked inflection points in web history. 

Here is a summary of my observations:

ğŸ“„ Simplicity and Efficiency Holds: Foundational web technologies like static HTML and server-side rendering remain useful for delivering content that rarely changes or doesn't require dynamic processing. These technologies were great in the 90s and continue to be effective and cost-efficient solutions even in 2024 for many use cases.

ğŸ¨ User Experience Matters: From the introduction of CSS for enhanced web aesthetics to the development of SPAs for dynamic user interactions, the focus on improving user experience has led to the creation of more dynamic technologies for real-time DOM manipulation and improved data fetching, leading to better user experience.

âš¡ Interactivity and Real-Time Communication Are Essential: Technologies such as client-side rendering, AJAX, and WebSockets have redefined user engagement, providing experiences as smooth and responsive as those of desktop applications.

ğŸ›¡ï¸ Security and Performance Are Continuous Priorities: Technologies like WebAssembly offer robust security models and enhanced performance, enabling developers to create high-performant applications with improved security features.

ğŸš€ Innovation and Adaptability is Not Optional: Developers need to remain flexible and embrace new technologies like WebAssembly and dApps to create cutting-edge web applications that meet the expectations of modern users.

"Those who don't know tech history are doomed to repeat past engineering mistakes."

Read more down below ğŸ‘‡

#WorldWideWeb #WebHistory #WebTechnologies

Now is a good time to reflect upon my professional achievements in 2023.

Here are some of my highlights from the year gone by:

* Completed my PhD. I successfully delivered and defended my PhD thesis at KTH Royal Institute of Technology. This is a significant milestone for me after 5 years of dedicated research efforts.

* Landed a great job at SEB. After about 30 job applications, 10 interviews, and a few attractive offers, I happily joined SEB. Now Iâ€™m convinced that I made the right choice. 

* Got a paper accepted at IEEE TSE. I submitted a research paper that got accepted in the journal  Transactions on Software Engineering. This achievement marked a peak in my research career.

* Engaged with the tech community. I attended over 10 technical meetups in Stockholm. This allowed me to connect with the tech community while visiting companies such as Google, Amazon Web Services (AWS), Spotify, Cloudera, Goldman Sachs,  Combient, and more. I also contributed as a volunteer at Jfokus. 

* Expanded my online presence. I wrote 10 blog posts on my website, spoke at 4 events, and was featured in a podcast episode for the first time.

* Kept learning. I improved my Swedish significantly, completed 3 specializations on Coursera, read around 10 technical books, and listened to all episodes of the "Lex Friedman Podcast" and "Software Engineering Radio."

* Committed to fitness. I maintained a steady gym routine, hitting the gym at least 5 times a week, and ran the Blodomloppet Sverige (10km Stockholmâ€™s half marathon). There is no professional growth without good health, which for me means going to the gym regularly ğŸ˜€

For the next year, my professional focus is to create more technical content (inc. source code) and consume less content in general. 

Wishing everyone a Happy New Year! Let's make 2024 a year of growth and achievement.

posts.text:
Welcome CÃ©sar Soto Valero to speak at #Jfokus 2024 with a talk about #SBOM: Dancing on Thin Ice - Leveraging Software Bill of Materials
#supplychain #security

The Talk: Dancing on Thin Ice - Leveraging Software Bill of Materials

Are you sure that you know which software you're actually running and delivering to your clients? If your answer is "yes", think twice because most people don't.

To answer this question, the idea of building Software Bill of Materials (SBOMs) has recently emerged as a key concept to enable principled engineering of software supply chains. It extends the well-established concept of a "bill of materials", used in manufacturing physical goods, to the realm of software development. The purpose of SBOMs is to capture relevant information about the internals of a software artifact. This includes a complete inventory of all the third-party dependencies of the artifact and its build environment. Thus, answering the question regarding third-party code provenance.

Whether youâ€™re a Java security expert or just starting your journey to deploy robust software solutions, this session is for you. We'll delve into checksums, hierarchy, reproducibility, and production steps for SBOM producers. Let's unleash the benefits of using SBOMs to harden the software supply chain of real-world #Java projects! 

More info and registration: buff.ly/3Sd3GjR

Four years ago, we submitted a research paper to the journal IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering (TSE). The paper was REJECTED, but fortunately it was published in another good journal [1]. Considering that I spent 2h of preparation for this, my performance was not as good as expected. What else could have been worse?
